```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```



```{r gain the library}
install.packages(c("quantmod","PerformanceAnalytics","tibbletime"))
library(quantmod)
library(PerformanceAnalytics)
library(tibbletime)

```



```{r}

start <- as.numeric(as.POSIXct("2020-01-01", tz="UTC"))
end   <- as.numeric(Sys.time())

start_int <- as.integer(start)
end_int <- as.integer(end)

symbol <- "^RUT"
url <- sprintf("https://query1.finance.yahoo.com/v7/finance/download/%s?period1=%d&period2=%d&interval=1d&events=history&includeAdjustedClose=true",
  symbol, start_int, end_int
)


rut_df <- read.csv(url, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)


head(rut_df)
str(rut_df)

```

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

